text: when I drove here from Cardiff 50 years
ago the hills on either side of the
valley were scarred with tips black and
ugly and threatening now as I look back
down the valley from this cemetery they
gon bulldozed away or covered with grass
and trees the mining valleys of South
Wales are green again the river that
flows beneath me
was also black and dead and now it's
clean and children can play and fish in
shallows and the men of these valleys
unlike their fathers do not end their
day's work with lungs full of coal dust
I never met a miner who said he wanted
his son to follow him down the pit the
nation owed miners a debt of gratitude
for the wealth they helped create over
the centuries the mines have gone of
course but our generation owes something
different to the people of abof an
respect for the courage and dignity they
have shown for 50 years in dealing with
unimaginable grief but more than that
the children in these graves were
betrayed by the men in power decades ago
who refused to listen to their fathers
when they warned them that their little
school faced a mortal danger if a bhavan
stands for anything today apart from
unimaginable grief it stands as a
reminder of this authority must always
be challenged
